The existence of karma in the three realms will be explained in the Abhidharma-koÅ›a.
Craving and grasping in terms of afflictions will be explained in the Abhidharma-koÅ›a.
Thus, this dependent origination, if briefly explained, is only threefold, namely afflictions, karma, and the fruits of karma.
The meaning of these three has already been shown.
Verse:
Among them, the afflictions are said to be like seeds, dragons, roots, trees, and husks.
Explanation:
How are these afflictions similar to seeds?
Just as sprouts, leaves, etc. arise from seeds, so too do afflictions, karma, and their fruits arise from afflictions.
Moreover, just as a pond that is inhabited by a dragon is always not dry, so too does the pond of birth inhabited by the dragon of afflictions continue without interruption.

Furthermore, just as a tree that has not had its roots pulled out grows again and again when cut down, so too do the paths that have not had their roots, the afflictions, pulled out arise again and again when extinguished.
Just as a tree produces flowers and fruits from time to time, so these afflictions repeatedly produce afflictions and actions.

Just as rice is wrapped in husks and has the ability to produce sprouts, not just rice alone, so this action, wrapped in the husks of afflictions and attainment, has the ability to produce another birth, not just action alone.
Thus these afflictions should be understood as being like seeds, etc.
The verse states:
Like rice with husks, action, and like rice with flowers.
The commentary states:
Previously it was said that afflictions are like husks, now it is said that action is like rice with husks.
Moreover, just as rice, bananas, etc. have their end in the state of ripe fruit, so these actions, once ripe, do not produce results again.
Moreover, just as a flower is the proximate cause in producing a fruit, so this action is the most proximate cause in producing its result.
The verse states:
Like cooked food and drink.
The commentary states:
Just as cooked food and drink are exclusively for enjoyment and cannot be transformed back into the raw state,
In this way, the class of retribution cannot attract another retribution in another birth; if it did attract another retribution, there would be no possibility of liberation.

In this way, the continuity of birth, arising from causes and conditions, does not go beyond the four existences, namely, intermediate existence, birth existence, prior existence, and death existence.
These four have already been explained above.
Verse:
Among the four existences, birth existence is definitely defiled.
Explanation:
Among them, how many existences are definitely defiled or not defiled?
If it is only defiled, it is only birth existence.
By what delusion?
Verse:
By the delusions of one's own stage.
Explanation:
If birth existence is in this stage, all the delusions of the same stage defile it. In the three realms, there is no single delusion by which beings do not undergo rebirth.
The Abhidharma masters say:
This defilement is by the great delusions, not by the minor delusions, because of mastery.
If this state is the most dull and obtuse, then the affliction that has arisen frequently before and is most proximate will arise in this state as defilement, because it is most acute.
Should one understand that the intermediate state is necessarily defiled in this way?
The verse states:
The other three.
The commentary explains:
The remaining three existences, namely the intermediate existence and so forth, each have three types: wholesome, defiled, and indeterminate.
Among the various existences, how many existences are associated with which realm?
The verse states:
The formless realm has three.
The commentary explains:
Excluding the intermediate existence, the remaining existences.
Why is it so?

Because the formless realm is not a separate location, one does not give rise to an intermediate existence in order to reach it. Since it is not counted in the desire and form realms, it should be understood that all have four existences.
The meaning of sentient beings being born based on causes and conditions has already been extensively explained.
If sentient beings have already been born, how do they abide?
The verse states:
The world abides through food.
The explanation is as follows:
The Buddha himself has realized and knows by himself, and teaches others, that all sentient beings are sustained by food.
The sÅ«tra says this.
How many kinds of food are there?
There are four kinds.
The verse says:
Coarse food.
The explanation says:

Coarse food is either coarse or fine. Fine food is the food of sentient beings in the intermediate state, because they eat smells, and the food of gods and sentient beings at the beginning of the eon, because it does not produce waste.
This food all enters their bodies, like oil in sand.
Moreover, if the sentient beings are fine, their food is also fine, like the lice and so on.
Contact food is second, mental intention food is third, and consciousness food is fourth.
Among them, coarse food, the verse says:
In the desire realm.
The explanation says:
This food does not exist in the form and formless realms, because those born there are free from desire for it.
The verse says:
It takes the three sense bases as its essence.
The Treatise says:
In the desire realm, all forms, smells, tastes, and touches are called food because they are ingested by being taken in morsels.
First, they are held in the mouth and nose, and then swallowed in small bites.
How can shadows, light, flames, and luster become food?
This is said based on the majority of cases.
If these are not ingested but can still sustain continuity, they are also included in the category of subtle food, like bathing, anointing, and so on.
How can the form sense base not be food?
If it is food, it must be about form.
The verse says:
The form sense base is not food because it does not benefit its own sense organ and is not liberated.
The Treatise says:
What is food?
If it can benefit its own sense organ and the four great elements.
When the form sense base is eaten, it cannot benefit its own sense organ and the four great elements, let alone benefit other sense organs and the four great elements.
Because it is not its own object.
Sometimes seeing form gives rise to pleasure and joy, but this form is also not food;
But it is only when it is the object of contact that it produces pleasant feeling, etc. Therefore it is food, not form.
Moreover, those who have attained liberation, namely non-returners and arhats, see desirable food and drink as having no benefit.
The verse says:
Contact, attention, and consciousness are the two that flow through the three.
The commentary says:
Contact arises from the combination of the three. Attention is the function of the mind. Consciousness is the mental consciousness.
These three, if they are contaminated, are necessarily food. These three are found in all three realms.
Why are the uncontaminated not established as food?
Because food is established as that which nourishes and increases existence. The uncontaminated give rise to the extinction of existence. The VaibhÄá¹£ikas hold this view.

Moreover, the meaning of food is explained in the sÅ«tras. There are four kinds of food that enable sentient beings who have already been born to remain and continue, and also benefit sentient beings who are seeking birth.
Uncontaminated dharmas are not like this, and therefore they are not nutriments.
Those who have already been born are sentient beings who have already been born in the path. This meaning is easy to understand.
What is the birth of searching?
The verse says:
Mind-born, birth of searching, gandharva, intermediate existence, and existence of meeting.
The commentary says:
The World-Honored One uses these five names to refer to sentient beings in the intermediate existence.
Why is this?
Because these sentient beings are born from the mind, they are called mind-born. They do not take impure substances such as blood as their support for birth.
Those born from searching are those who have not yet attained birth but seek birth everywhere because they desire to attain birth.
Gandharvas are so called because they benefit their bodies by eating fragrances and proceed towards the path by relying on fragrances.
The existence of meeting is so called because they meet and approach the place of birth.
As a sutra says:
Meeting arises with obstruction, harming one's own body. Birth arises with obstruction, harming the world.
For this reason, the existence of meeting is called the intermediate existence.
There is another sutra that says:
There are sentient beings who have already eliminated the fetters of existence but not the fetters of birth.
This sutra has four sentences.
Furthermore, those who have already been born refer to arhats.
Those who seek birth refer to sentient beings with craving for existence.
Furthermore, how many kinds of food make sentient beings who have already been born abide?
How many kinds of food can nourish and benefit sentient beings who seek birth?
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters say:
All foods can do both things.
Why is this?
Material food also causes sentient beings with craving for existence to obtain subsequent existence.
The Buddha, the World-Honored One, said:
There are four foods that are the roots of illness, boils, thorns, old age, death, and so forth.
Attention food has also been seen to cause the present life to abide. The ancient masters say:
There was a father who encountered famine and difficulty. He filled a bag with ashes and hung it on the wall, comforting his two children and saying it was flour.
The two children often thought of the bag of flour and remained at ease for a long time.
Later, someone opened it, and they knew it was ashes. Losing their original intention, they immediately died.
Furthermore, in the ocean, many people, when their ship was wrecked, saw a large mass of waves and thought it was the shore, so they went towards it.
When they arrived and touched it, they realized it was waves. Losing their original intention, they immediately died.
In the separate recitation, it is said:
In the ocean, there are large-bodied beings who emerge from the water onto the shore, lay their eggs on the sand, cover them with sand, and return to the ocean.
If the mother does not forget to remember these eggs, they will not be destroyed;
if the mother forgets them, the eggs will be destroyed.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas explain it differently, lest by the eating of another, the eating of another be accomplished.
If it is to be explained like this:
in the middle, if the eggs are conditioned by the mother's memory not being forgotten, the eggs will not be destroyed;
if forgotten, they will be destroyed.
Other masters say:
this memory is in the state of contact.
Why are only four nutriments taught?
Isn't it so?
Although all defiled dharmas can nourish existence, still they are taught because of their superiority.
A verse says:
For the sake of nourishing the supported and the support, and for the sake of attracting and producing separately, the latter two are taught in order.
The commentary says:
The support refers to the body with faculties. For nourishing this body, material food is superior.
The supported refers to mind and mental factors. For nourishing these dharmas, contact food is superior.
In this way, these two foods are superior to the others in nourishing the present existence that has already arisen.
The establishment of intention food is for the sake of attracting a subsequent existence. The existence that is attracted arises from the seeds of consciousness perfumed by karma.
In this way, the latter two are superior to the others in attracting the future existence that has not yet arisen.
The former two foods are like wet nurses, because they nourish what has already arisen;
the latter two foods are like birth mothers, because they give birth to what has not yet arisen.
Because they are superior to the others, only four are established.
Are all the portions swallowed food?
There are four alternatives regarding the portions swallowed.
The first alternative is when swallowing this portion, the faculties are damaged and the four great elements are harmed.
The second alternative is the other three foods.
The third alternative is the portions swallowed that nourish the faculties and increase the four great elements.
The fourth alternative is excluding the first three alternatives.
In this way, contact and so on should each be established with four alternatives according to reason.
Are there any conditions of contact and so on that can nourish the faculties and increase the four great elements, but are not food?
Yes, namely those of different stages and the uncontaminated.
The other alternatives should be considered:
If a person eats this food and damages the faculties and great elements of the eater, this substance is also food, because it is grasped as food from the beginning.
Why is this?
Because coarse food functions as food in two periods of time.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that when one is eating, it remedies the original illness, and when it is digested, it benefits the body and increases its size.
In which realms are there how many nutriments?
In all realms there are all four nutriments, and the same is true for birth.
How can there be material food in hell?
There is burning red-hot iron as food, and molten copper as drink.
If that which harms is also food, then it contradicts the previous four statements, and also contradicts the VibhÄá¹£Ä.
That treatise says:
What is material food?

If it nourishes the faculties by being divided into parts, increases the continuity of the four great elements, and heals, and the same is true for consciousness, it is explained in detail in the treatise.
Because it is said in terms of that which increases and benefits food, there is no contradiction.
Harming food also has the characteristics of food in hell.
Why is this?
Because this food has the ability to temporarily relieve illnesses such as hunger and thirst.

Furthermore, there is another place in hell where there is coarse food, just as there is in the human realm. Therefore, coarse food exists in all five realms of existence. This meaning should be accepted.
The World-Honored Buddha said:

If a person offers food to a hundred seers who have transcended desire in the desire realm, and if another person offers food to a single ordinary person who practices in the Jeta Grove, the merit of the latter offering surpasses the former by a hundred thousand times.
Who is this ordinary person who practices in the Jeta Grove?
Other teachers say:
He abides in the Jeta Grove.
Some say:
He is an ordinary person with merit.
This interpretation is not correct, because it speaks of one.
Why is the merit of offering food to a single ordinary person greater than offering to many seers who have transcended desire?
If it is said that offering food to many ordinary people is more meritorious than offering to a single ordinary person, this meaning is acceptable.
Other teachers say:
He is a bodhisattva who is close to the stage of buddhahood.
Other masters do not explain this meaning.
Why is it so?
If one gives to this bodhisattva, the merit is the most, and cannot be measured.
If one gives to this person, the merit obtained is not even as much as giving to a hundred koá¹­is of arhats.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters say:
There are ordinary beings who have already attained the ability to penetrate the four truths. This is what is meant by practicing in the dense forest of JambudvÄ«pa.

This name does not correspond with the meaning, and it has never been established elsewhere, only in this case, namely in the sÅ«tras and Abhidharma piá¹­aka, it is said that one who practices in the dense forest of JambudvÄ«pa must attain the ability to penetrate the four truths. Therefore, this is one's own discrimination.
If so, then what?
It is definitely about the bodhisattva who is practicing in the dense forest of JambudvÄ«pa, therefore this is said.
Why is it so?

Because this bodhisattva at this time is associated with two meanings of ordinary people and separation from desire of the desire realm, he distinguishes other sages and makes them different from this bodhisattva, surpassing countless beings by immeasurable times.
But it is said to be a hundred times, because it must be so according to what was established before.
Why is this?
Because this person is compared to the external sages in order to measure the stream-enterer.
If it were not so, one would have to compare the stream-enterer to one who practices in the dense forest of JambudvÄ«pa.
The meaning of sentient beings being born depending on causes and conditions, and the meaning of sentient beings being able to abide, have already been explained.
The meaning of sentient beings dying and falling has also been explained, namely, due to the exhaustion of blessings, not due to the exhaustion of life, and so on.
This meaning will now be explained.
In which consciousness does a sentient being die and fall, and in which does it receive rebirth?
The verse says:
Cutting off, connecting, abandoning desires, regressing, dying, and receiving rebirth - these events occur in the mental consciousness.
The commentary says:

The severance of the wholesome roots, the reconnection of the wholesome roots, the detachment from the lower realms, the falling away from the higher realms, death and rebirth - these six dharmas are accomplished in the mental consciousness, not in the other consciousnesses.
Because of the mention of rebirth, the meaning of the intermediate state is also what is being discussed.
If it is said that one experiences death and rebirth, how is it?
The verse says:
Death and rebirth occur in the feeling of equanimity.
It is explained that death and rebirth occur in the feeling of neither-painful-nor-pleasant. This feeling is dull,
while the other feelings are clear. Death and rebirth do not occur in a clear consciousness.
In this mental consciousness, the verse says:
Not in one without mind, nor in two.
The explanation is:
Although death and rebirth occur in the mental consciousness, not in a single mind or in a mindless state.
Why is it so?
Because for one who is in a concentrated mind, there is no meaning of death and rebirth. Because the stage is not the same, because it is accomplished by effort, and because it can benefit.
One also cannot die in a mindless state.
Why is this?
For one without mind, there is no violent injury.
At that time, if the basis wishes to undergo a change, then the mind belonging to the basis will definitely arise and manifest, and only then will one give up life, not otherwise.
If at the time of rebirth there is no mind, that also should not be so, because the cause of the cessation of mind does not exist.
Because without the upper mind and afflictions, one cannot take rebirth.
Therefore, it is not reasonable that there is no mind in that state.
There are three kinds of death, as explained above.
The verse states:
Nirvana and the two indeterminate [minds].
The commentary explains:
In the mind of deportment and the mind of retribution, if in the desire realm there is a retribution called equanimity,
if not, one attains nirvana in the mind of deportment.
Why is it only in the indeterminate mind and not in other minds?
This indeterminate mind accords with the cessation of mind, because it is weak in power.
When a person is dying, in which part of the body does consciousness cease?
If death is instantaneous, the bodily faculties and consciousness cease simultaneously.
If death is gradual, a verse states:
Gradually, death occurs in the feet, navel, and heart, with consciousness ceasing. Those not reborn as humans or gods.
The commentary states:
If a person is destined to be reborn in the evil destinies, human realm, or celestial realm, for such a person, death occurs gradually in the feet, navel, and heart, with consciousness ceasing.
Not being reborn again is called non-arising, referring to arhats, for whom consciousness ceases.
Other schools say it occurs in the head.
Why is it so?
Because the bodily faculties cease together with consciousness in these places.
When a person is dying, the bodily faculties gradually shrink like water on a hot stone, ceasing gradually in the feet and other parts.
Furthermore, if sentient beings die in this order, many sentient beings are oppressed by the pain of the final agony before death.
What is the final agony?
The verse says:
The final agony is water, etc.
The commentary says:
The final agony is a specific place in the body.
As a verse says:
There is such a place in the body, where being touched leads to death,
Even by the slight touch of a pollen particle of an utpala flower.
Therefore, it is known that there is a specific place in the body, where if it is damaged by a touch, it can lead to death. This part of the body is called the final agony.
This final agony, if one of the three great elements - water, wind, or fire - arises in a way that is contrary to its nature, it is as if it were cut by a sharp blade and immediately destroyed.
This is unlike firewood, etc., which is cut and immediately severed. It is like being cut and immediately losing all sense of movement, so it is called the final agony.
Why not by the earth element?
Because there is no fourth illness.

The three illnesses of wind, heat, and phlegm, in order, take wind, fire, and water as their primary elements, similar to the three calamities of the external world. Therefore, there are three calamities within the body.

This kind of death by the suffering of being cut by a saw mostly occurs for those who frequently engage in cutting others with a saw. This person will definitely die by the suffering of being cut by a saw.
In the heavens, there is no death by the suffering of being cut by a saw.
Nevertheless, if the heavenly beings are about to fall, five kinds of small changes will appear first:

1. Unpleasant sounds come from their clothes and ornaments, 2. their bodily light becomes dim, 3. water droplets stick to their bodies when bathing, 4. their minds, which used to be restless among objects, now dwell on one object, 5. their eyes blink.
These five are sometimes uncertain.
There are also five kinds of great changes that definitely cannot be avoided before death:

First, the clothes become stained and dirty; second, the flower garlands wither and dry up; third, sweat appears under the armpits; fourth, foul odors enter the body; fifth, one cannot sit comfortably in one's own seat.
Such are the beings and worlds, such is the birth, abiding, and decline.
The World-Honored Buddha establishes the three groups to include all beings.
There are three groups:
First, the group of those with right determination; second, the group of those with wrong determination; third, the group of those without right determination.
A verse says:
Those with right determination and those with wrong determination are created by the sages without interruption.
The commentary says:
What is meant by right?
Completely eliminating desire, completely eliminating anger, completely eliminating delusion, and completely eliminating all afflictions is called right.
The sutra says this.
The sages, if in the continuity of this person the uncontaminated path has already arisen, are called sages.
Why are they called sages?
They are able to escape from the dharma of falling into evil, because they have attained the fruit of definite and permanent separation.
Such people are called those of right disposition because their delusions are exhausted and determined.
If a person has already attained the roots of goodness that lead to liberation, and is definitely destined for nirvana, why are they not established as those of right disposition?
This person will later fall into wrong disposition.
This person is not determined in the right by temporal determination.
It is like the seven superior ones and so forth.
What is wrong?
The destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts are called wrong.
Here, a person who commits the uninterrupted offenses is determined in the destiny of hell, and is therefore called one of wrong disposition.
If different from the two determinations, the rest are not determined, this meaning is established by itself.
These three groups observe causes and conditions, belonging to two and not belonging to two.
Having explained the world of sentient beings, the world of the vessel will now be explained.
Verse:
In this, the world of the vessel is said to be based on the lower support, sixteen koá¹­is deep, and the wind wheel is immeasurable in breadth.
Explanation:
In the trichiliocosm, the Buddhas speak of the profound and vast, namely, the wind wheel at the bottom, which is born from the dominant karma of sentient beings.
This wind wheel is sixteen laká¹£as and yojanas thick, and its length and breadth are innumerable. It is as solid as this.
If a person with the strength of a great nÄga were to strike it with a vajra scepter, the vajra would shatter, but the wind wheel would not be damaged.
Above the wind wheel, the verse says:
The water wheel is eleven deep, and there are twenty thousand [more].
The commentary says:
Above the wind wheel, due to the dominant karma of sentient beings, the clouds gather and rain falls like a great pillar.
This water wheel forms, eleven laká¹£as and twenty thousand yojanas deep.
How is it that the water wheel does not flow out sideways?
Due to the dominant power of the karma of sentient beings.
It is like food and drink. If these foods and drinks have not yet been digested, they do not fall into the stomach, other teachers say this is so.
Or rather, like food, it is held together by the wind, so that it does not disperse. This is the opinion of other masters.

Moreover, this water is agitated by the wind, which is in turn agitated by the force of the actions of beings. The cream which rises to the surface becomes gold. It is like milk which, when it is churned, becomes cream.ğŸ”½The water is 80,000 leagues deep; the rest is gold.
The rest is gold.

Three hundred and thirty-six thousand leagues. This is the circle of gold, which rests on the circle of water.ğŸ”½The thickness of the water and gold together is 160,000 leagues.
The diameter of the circle of water and gold is 1,200,000 leagues.

If measured by the edge, the number becomes three times, totaling thirty-six koá¹­is, ten thousand, three hundred and fifty yojanas.
The golden ground wheel is on the water.
In this ground, the verse says:
There are Mount Sumeru, Yugandhara Mountain, Äªá¹£Ädhara Mountain, Khadiraka Mountain, SudarÅ›ana Mountain, AÅ›vakará¹‡a Mountain, Vinataka Mountain, and Nimindhara Mountain.
The explanation is as follows:
These mountains are located above the golden ground wheel.

The first is Yugandhara, the second is Äªá¹£Ädhara, the third is Khadiraka Mountain, the fourth is SudarÅ›ana, the fifth is AÅ›vakará¹‡a, the sixth is Vinataka, and the seventh is Nimindhara.
This Mount Sumeru is surrounded by seven mountain ranges, and the outermost mountain range is named Nimindhara.
Verse:
Outside the four continents, there is another CakravÄla mountain.
Explanation:
Outside the seventh mountain, there are four continents. Outside the four continents, there is another iron CakravÄla mountain.
Because of this mountain, the world's appearance is round like a wheel.
In the middle, it is said in a verse:
Seven are gold, this is iron.
Explanation:
The seven mountains such as Yugandhara are all composed of gold. This outermost mountain is only composed of iron.
Verse:
The four treasures are Sumeru.
Explanation:
On the four sides, they are composed of the four treasures in order: gold, silver, lapis lazuli, and crystal.
The sides are according to the treasures that compose them. Because of the light, in the directions the empty color appears like the original treasure.
Facing the continent of JambudvÄ«pa, the side of Sumeru is composed of lapis lazuli. Because of the light of this treasure, the empty space is seen as blue, like lapis lazuli.
Furthermore, how are these jewels produced?

On the golden ground, there are also clouds that rain water droplets like chariot axles. This water is the womb for various seeds, with various powerful distinctions. The wind blows and transforms this water, turning it into various kinds of jewels.

This transformation is the general and specific production of different kinds of things, due to the principle of non-existence before and non-simultaneity. It is able to act as a cause and condition, unlike the transformation theory established by the SÄá¹ƒkhya non-Buddhist school.
The SÄá¹ƒkhya transformation means that this thing first already exists and transforms into a different dharma.
If so, what is the fault?
This existent dharma cannot be understood.
This dharma already exists, due to the existence of distinctions among the other dharmas within it.
Who says this?
From dharma, there is a different dharma. This dharma class is not different. It is only said to be transformation by establishing the characteristic of difference.
If so, it is also not reasonable.
Why is it unreasonable?
This thing is just that, and that is not this, as it has never existed before.
This is the principle of verbal expression.

In this way, when gold and other treasures have already been gathered and produced, there is a separate wind arisen by the power of karma. This wind can gather the treasures together in one place, forming mountains and continents.
The place where they are gathered forms the inner and outer seas, Mount Sumeru and other mountains, with the Iron Encircling Mountains at the end.
The verse states:
The water enters eighty thousand [yojanas].
The commentary states:
On the golden ground there is water, eighty thousand yojanas deep. The various mountains enter it in order.
The verse states:
These mountains emerge from the water, also eighty thousand yojanas.
The commentary states:
In this way, Mount Sumeru is one hundred and sixty thousand yojanas high.
The verse states:
The eight mountains are half as high as the previous one.
The commentary states:
Mount Yugandhara is forty thousand yojanas high above the water, half as high as Mount Sumeru.
The Yisha Tuo Luo Mountain is half the height of the You Jian Tuo Luo Mountain.
In this way, it should be known that the height of the other mountains decreases by half in sequence.
Down to the Iron Encircling Mountain, the height of the Ni Min Tuo Luo Mountain is three hundred and twelve and a half yojanas.
The verse states:
The height and width are equal.
The commentary states:
The height of the mountains above the water is the same as their width.
The verse states:
In between them are seven seas.
The commentary states:
The Ni Min Tuo Luo Mountain is the last. In between them are seven seas filled with water possessing the eight qualities.
This water is cool, sweet, light, soft, clear, fragrant, does not hurt the throat when drunk, and benefits the internal organs when drunk without harming the stomach.
In these seven seas, the verse states:
The first sea is eighty thousand yojanas wide.
The commentary states:
Inside the You Jian Tuo Luo Mountain, this is the first sea, eighty thousand yojanas wide.
This is called the inner ocean.
The explanation is as follows:
There are two kinds of oceans, one inner and one outer.
As for the inner oceans between these two mountains, the verse states:
Each side is three times [the width of the inner ocean].
The explanation is as follows:

It has been said that this ocean is 80,000 yojanas wide. If counted from the inner side of the CakravÄá¸a mountains, each side is three times [the width of the inner ocean], totaling 240,000 yojanas in width.
The verse states:
The remaining oceans are half the width of the previous ones.
The explanation is as follows:
Between the CakravÄá¸a and Äªá¹£ÄdhÄra mountains is the second ocean, half the width of the first ocean, 40,000 yojanas wide.
Half the width of the second is the third, and thus by half the width of the previous ones, the width of the remaining oceans should be known. Up to the seventh, it is 1,250 yojanas wide.
The length is not stated because it has many different measurements.
The verse states:
The remaining ones are called the outer oceans.
The explanation is as follows:
What are the remaining ones?
